page.description: Converts a number to a character string.
page.syntax: Formatted_String as C = STR(N number[,N length[,N decimal_places[,C number_format]]])

argument.name: length
argument.description: Optional. Default (10). The number of characters in the Formatted_String. Refer to Number Formats for more information.

argument.name: decimal_places
argument.description: Optional. Default (0). The number of characters after the decimal point in the Formatted_String. If you do not specify decimal places, STR() rounds the Number to the nearest whole number.

argument.name: number_format
argument.description: Default (""). The pattern to use when formatting Formatted_String. Values for Format are:

item.description: Displays a number as a percentage.
Separates thousands with the thousands separator.

item.name: X
item.description: Formats the number in words (e.g. for checkbook applications).

page.discussion: STR() converts a Number to a right-justified character string. The optional Length parameter determines the length of the string, and the optional Decimal_Places parameter specifies the number of decimal places. The length must allow space for decimals, the decimal point, and a - or + sign. Note : Because STR() returns a string with a right-justified number, you may want to use the LTRIM() function to remove leading spaces before using the string in other operations.

section.description: You may need to order the records in a table on multiple fields that are of different types. For example, you may want to create an index to display records in DEPARTMENT order, and within DEPARTMENT by SALARY.

Alpha Anywhere enables you to create new text strings by concatenating existing strings. The individual pieces to be concatenated must all be character strings. You, therefore, have to convert numeric fields to character strings before they can be concatenated to other fields. The following expression, for example, returns a date in the format "Month DD, YYYY" (e.g., November 11, 1968).
